reviewText:
Fantastic blend of gameplay based world-building, smallish-but-very-tall-open-world exploration, immersive and dynamic mechanics, and beautiful floating island world.

Think Jack and the Beanstalk meets Wall-E.

Also with parachute/glider/jetpack in contextual forms.  'Sept the jetpack, you get a real jetpack as a reward for all the crystals.

Sorry if you only enjoy graphically rich games, must be sad to be you.

This game doesn't have much content other than the collecting and worldbuilding, but it makes up for that by being cheap and really fun to just climb around in and grow your massive plant.  You could easily invest hours into this game if you're the kind of person that plays Assassin's Creed just to climb around on stuff for hours.

Here's my recommendation in the hopes that this isn't the only game to come out of this idea.  Oh, and next time, multiplayer plz?  IMHO tons of opportunity there for great gameplay.. Race to the top of the world anyone?  Using the climbing mechanic to pull another player off the stalk or skydive into their glider for a daring trade of places?

reviewText:
I don't usually like artsy games like this, but it scratches a similar itch to Minecraft where you build the stalk, and then look at what you've just done. SPOILER: The crystals boost your rocket power, at least up to 60% crystal, so that helps a ton.

It's taken me about 2 hours to grow the stalk out and do a bit of the post game, but that's long enough, towards the end the beanstalk growing was getting a little tedious.

Overall, the game's worth checking out. Super casual though.

reviewText:
I can hardly believe this game was developed by a studio owned by Ubisoft :D

It's very enjoyable and refreshing. It has an excellent visual style and sound design that is both endearing and serves to temper player expectations of how well things like the procedural animation system will work. Which is to say that the procedural animation is far from perfect. It's wonky and weird, but it works perfectly with the game's tone and visuals.

This is a game that clearly started as a prototype with fun mechanics and then had everything else designed to play to its strengths and distract from its weaknesses; which is how all games should be designed, in my opinion.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying that this is one of the most charming, intuitive games I have played for a long time.

You are a robot,  B.U.D

You are dropped from 2km down to the bottom of a beautiful world. The Cell Shaded graphics look absolutely fantastic, and remind me of Wind Waker dearly. The controls are pretty simple, but I would reccomend playing with a controller (I found it a bit fiddly with a mouse and keyboard). The proceedingly generated movement animation works a lot of the time, but can glitch a bit when you are climbing at a strange angle. The game is fairly easy once you get the hang of it, but it is best played (IMO) when you are tired, and can't be bothered for some twitchy Counterstrike. Stick on some calm background music (or listen to the game's soundtrack, which is very soothing) and this game is very calming.

There is a fair bit of content for the money. You could probably complete the main quest in an hour if you tried as fast as possible, but you would be missing so much more. By collecting gems, you can unlock new abilities (One complaint I have with this is that the first ability unlocked is a better in game camera, WTF? That should be there from the start). There are also tasks after you have finished the main mission as well. I would like to see some community made maps and hopefully some more content from the devs, but I am struggling for complaints about the game now.

Go Buy It! I r8 8/8 m8
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The best way to describe this game is delightful. It's so lighthearted, cheery, and FUN that I can't believe this was published by Ubisoft. I highly recommend this for anyone looking to take a break from gritty, realistic, violent, and dark games, or really just anyone in general. It has some flaws, to be sure, but I'd love to see a sequel that improves upon the few failings that it has.

Positives:
-Fantastic and unique platforming
-Growing a massive tree lets you build the level as you play it
-The art style is simplistic, expressive, and pleasant to look at
-The lighting is fantastic
-M.O.M
-The most fun I've had climbing in a game
-It's so much fun to play in general
-It can be completed in under 3 hours

Negatives
-Leveling system feels tacked on. It's not terrible but it should either be improved or removed
-No map/icons means that it's extremely difficult to find all 100 collectible crystals and the 8 collectible seeds.
-Atmosphere decreases(tougher gliding) but gravity doesn't as you go higher up (makes platforming feel sluggish). This is only really a problem towards the very end of the first part of the game, but it's still a problem.
-Glide Flower is superseded completely by Glide Leaf. System should be improved or removed
-Climbing is occasionally wonky
-Short length may be a turn off to some people

Overall, I definitely recommend this game. I hope that there is a sequel, but I'd even be happy with just this. Buy it at full price, it's worth the cost

reviewText:
This game is a little gem that warms my heart when I even think of the fun I had while playing it.

Graphics - Creative and blocky. A very colorful world with an adorable design to it.

Gameplay - The game feels very polished, and the graple system feels so right! You honestly feel your little robot claws digging into the mountain to avoid falling to certain doom.

Story - Simple, yet deep. The story is basically to collect things and sample the alien life on the planet, but it feels like so much more than that. Honestly almost cried when it was all over.

Replayablility - Sadly, as it stands this game doesn't have much replayability with only having one map. I hope the devs keep up with this project and add so much more to it!

It is sad to see this game overlooked due to Ubisoft being the main publishing company, as they aren't highly looked up to in the eyes of even the most casual gamer. But please, if you have $8.00 to spend, please consider buying this game. It will change your life.

5/5

reviewText: Can whole heartedly recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a bit of an escape from the gritty realism of gaming today. I have completed the game already (yes it is a very short game) but there is a side quest once you finish the main which will probably take me another hour or two to finish so the game is short but I feel like it is so fun that it will be something that I will be coming back to time and time again. Basically the main gameplay surrounds the character B.U.D climbing his way around a giant plant and connecting this plant to floating sky islands to make the plant grow bigger (weird I know) anyway, this whole adventure is also accompanied by some neat little upgrades you can snag with the crystals laying around which will help you on your way and will distract you from the main goal if it gets a bit tedious. Making such a serene game with such simple rules and yet executing it so well is something that this game accomplishes in droves, have fun playing and watching little B.U.D get himself into all sorts of weird positions with the animation style they have gone for, which is basically just let physics take over and it is quite funny at times to see him bend over backwards after hitting a floating island too hard. Definitely pick this game up while it is on sale for a good few hours of entertainment.

reviewText:
This is just a beautiful game.

You play as B.U.D - the little robot that could - and you are tasked with growing an enormous plant up into the stratosphere until it sprouts its seeds for you to collect and send back home. On your way you'll explore a gorgeous floating island world teeming with interesting plants and cute animals. The biggest point of difference is the climbing feature which is best operated via a controller. Left and right triggers control B.U.D's ability to latch onto the the world around him, and once you get used to the mechanic you'll be scaling the environment like a pro.

When I laid down my money on this I thought it would be a couple of hours distraction, but I was shocked to realise that nearly 6 hours of my time felt like almost nothing. My only wish is that there was more, but that's not really a criticism.

reviewText:
*Skip to the bottom of the review for Tl:dr*

Grow home is a charming platformer from Reflections, a Ubisoft Studio. Released on Steam in February, it was received to high praise almost unanimously. I gave it a download this weekend, and now feel compelled to talk about the charming platformer.

Grow Home reminded me of Wall-E. You play as a lonely droid, BUD (Botanical Utility Droid), and MOM (missed what that stands for) drops you down onto a new planet. Your task is now to explore the planet’s biosphere and climb your way back to the mother ship by growing the star plant.

The world centres around a large plant which has off-shoots with red flowers. By climbing up onto these you can make them grow, extending the size and reach of the main plant. Spread around the world are floating land masses, some of which have glowing green bottoms. These provide power, and it’s your task to grow the off-shoots into these to receive their power. Doing this X times will cause the main plant to grow another stage, moving you ever-closer to the mothership.

It’s a simple premise, which could feel repetitive if not done correctly, but the charm of the world and novel controls negate that. The character controls somewhat like a ragdoll; it’s very reminiscent I Am Bread. You control each arm of the character with a different trigger, and direct him with the analogue stick. It feels great when you get into a nice rhythm, working your way up towards the mothership, but it does have a minor camera issue. For the most part the camera works great, but I did find myself sometimes babysitting it as the structure around me grew more complex. The game recommends using the gamepad, and I listened, so all my comments should be disregarded for keyboard controls as I’m sure it feels very different.

At various heights throughout the level there are teleporters to be found. These allow you fast-travel between land masses at different heights. There’s also no punishment for dying. BUD dies from substantial fall damage, however if you do so you’re simply returned to the last teleporter you used. These two things mean there’s no punishment for exploring and taking risks. If you want to attempt a crazy jump between branches you can. If you don’t make it you can try again. I love this about the game. It encourages exploration and doing crazy things, ready for when you make mistakes.

The main objective of the game is to grow the main plant and reach the mothership, but there’s lots to do in the world around you besides that. Throughout the world there are a number animals and plants to be found, some that require a lot of exploration to find! A running task is to find them all and bring them to a teleporter so MOM can scan them. Doing so will net you a new skin for BUD; there are other skins that can be unlocked by completing other tasks.

There are also 100 crystals spread through the level. Some of these are really hard to find, and I found ~85 before resorting to a guide! Collecting these will unlock updates to BUD, giving you greater control over his movement. For example, when you reach around 60 crystals, you unlock a jetpack that gives you significantly more movement control.

One of the main things I love about Grow Home is the environment itself. Low poly isn’t for everyone, but, when done right, minimalistic environment just look amazing. If ever I’d want to show somewhat what low poly should look like I’d point them towards Grow Home. It has so much charm and whimsy with the bright simple colours and shapes. Pair that with the underlying ambient soundtrack and it’s just an awesome environment.

I do feel though that the relationship the player has with BUD could be greater. He is a cute little robot, but it doesn’t really go deeper than that. Like I mentioned earlier, it reminds me strongly of Wall-E, but you feel a lot more for Wall-E; you are always really routing for him. I didn’t feel that with BUD. He was merely a tool, a cute one, but nonetheless a tool in which I moved around the environment. I felt really warm and in-touch with the environment, but no so much BUD.

Tl:dr – Grow Home is a charming platformer, with quirky controls and lovable protagonist. While short, and not without its minor issues such as camera control, its price and charisma overshadow these minor shortcomings to provide a wonderfully whimsical experience.

Rating - 9/10

Visit http://www.indiegamers.co.uk for more indie game news and reviews.

reviewText:
I bought this game pretty much on visuals alone. I know it's not normally the best way to judge whether or not to purchase a game, but sometimes I just want something pretty to look at for an hour or so and Grow Home definitely did not dissapoint. The game was so charming I'd find myself no longer trying to grab collectibles or grow the plant and finish the game but rather gliding around taking in the sites and views. If Grow Home were ever to be made into a multi-staged game of short levels but with more content I'd buy it in a heartbeat.

The game only has about 7 hours of gameplay, and that's if you want to get all the achievements. Many people could probably finish it faster than that, but like I said I got sidetracked. I typically wait until games cost about $1 per hour of gameplay, more or less depending upon the game's reviws. I bought this game real cheap during the summer sale, but I'd pay the full price to experience it for the first time all over again.

The controls are intentionally clunky and sometimes downright frustrating, but I'm pretty sure that's the point. The crystals aren't easy to track, but not impossible to find. I got to 99/100 before breaking down and checking out a guide, only to realize I simply didn't sweep the last area well enough. Otherwise, it was fairly easy to grab everything without missing any.

All in all, I'd give the game an 8.5/10.

reviewText: There is just something so satisfying about Grow Home; its charm is delightful and controlling BUD feels great. reviewText:
One SentenceAn open world 3D platformer/climber full of charm and exploration.

A Bit MoreGrow Home is a wonderful platformer with lots of climbing elements, mostly early on before your get movement upgrades. You will find yourself hanging on to floating island for dear life just to get to that next crystal piece or some cave you just found that you wish to explore. Controlling the hero (BUD) is not easy at first, you will slip and fall and drown and die many times but it is an integral part of the game's humor and charm, along with the great visuals.
The game must be played with a gamepad as far as I'm concerned as they climbing mechanics with the LT RT works the best.

Bottom Line6-10 hours of fun platforming and climbing for 5-8$ is worth it for me. Grow Home is a unique gem on steam for any 3D platformers fans.

Follow http://steamcommunity.com/groups/West7 for more game reviews

reviewText:
First, don't mind the grammar XD

Searching for a game which makes you feel you are having a cozy dream?
When sometimes you don't know what's up and what's down?
When it's all relaxed and you still have some form of suspense?
That you want a game to be simple, yet exciting?

Then look no further: This is it!
You are a robot send to a planet and your goal is to climb and make a plant grow.
The robot appears to be in a drunk state, which in my opinion only adds to the suspense of not falling down :)
Sounds boring? You would be surprised. Be sure to have a Game pad at hand, plays the best way in my opinion.

1. No need for Uplay! Just install and play :D
2. Open world game play.
3. Simple yet appealing to the eye.
4. No Cod-blasting-all-around-you-kill-everyting-that-moves-gameplay.
5. Very... VERY chilling sounds/music.
6. Perspective changing, sort of riding a roller coaster.
7. Discover new environments, plants, animals etc.

Like I said before, if you have a game pad then use it. I'm using a Xbox controller and it plays very well.
No, the graphics aren't state of the art. But if that's the only thing you care about then this game is not for you.
I got the game on Steam sale and it was well worth the buy for the price.
Only played it for a hour so perhaps my opinion about this game might change, but so far it's really nice.

So if you can get it cheap then do so, it's good entertainment ^-^

reviewText:
Grow home is a quite original indie title from the Reflections team at Ubisoft(!)

You're B.U.D. (Botanical Utility Droid) and you have to grow the Star Plant 2000 meters into the sky where your space ship awaits. You do this by growing branches (Star Shoots) from the main stalk into energy rocks that float around the sky.  Every time you connect with a energy rock, the star plant grows a little taller.

The practical discipline of growing a star shoot is to climb onto a flower on the stalk and press a button - this will send you riding this wiggly branch in the direction you attempt to steer.

Apart from growing the Star Plant you can also go look for crystals, which will award you with certain very practical power-ups.

Even though it's all rendered with flat shaded polygons, the palette, level design and creatures still manage to look quite lush and pretty. Since you'll probably end up growing quite a bit of failed star shoots that didn't manage to connect with anything, the sky will eventually look like a messy web of green snakes.

In the gameplay department, I have to say that the process of climbing itself  is a bit too tedious and slow. And this is a problem when you'll be doing so very much of it. You basically alternate between two buttons while steering. You tend to lose focus, and miss a grab, and fall. Which means more redundant climbing ahead. A gamepad is very recommended!

Luckily you'll get a jet pack, and there are items in the levels that'll help with moving about as well. Flowers that'll act as a parachute, leaves usable as a hang glider, and leaves on the star plant which are basically jump pads and more.

Upon completing the immediate task of reaching the ship, you'll be tasked by finding 8 star seeds which are spread across the world. I felt I had just properly gotten the hang of it all at this point, so I went for it and ultimately after 4 hours of total playtime I had done this, gotten a decent amount of achievents and 80% of the crystals.

The game does have some quirks and issues, but if you enjoy original exploration games, I think you'll have fun which this one - I definately did.

73%

reviewText:
An absolutely delightful game featuring a beatiful polygononal environment. Grow Home is serene, peaceful, and engaging. Discovering new areas and exploring the environment are quite a joy. The main character controls in wonky way that somehow adds more charm to the game rather than frustrates it. The game is a real take-it-at-your-own-pace affair, no need to rush to the next objective, but you can press on ahead quickly enough if you so desire to do so.

Somewhat bizarrely, this game is made by Ubisoft. Which is weird, because it is nothing like any other Ubisoft game I have ever dealt with. It has no microtransactions, no Uplay, no massive open world full of repetitive side-missions, and no thosands of developers creating a two-hour-long credits sequence. In addition, not only is the PC version not a buggy piece of crap, there wasn't even a console release of the game until half a year later. This game feels like an indie game in all the right ways, even if it did come from Ubisoft.

The only shame is that the game is so short. There is so much more that could have been done here, yet I fear this potential will be left permanently, untapped.

reviewText:
10/10 doesn't require Uplay.

In all seriousness though, Grow Home is my favourite game of 2015.

It is short (about 5 hours of gameplay, a little more if you're hunting achievements) but the utter charm of Grow Home more than makes up for it.

Graphics: Low poly with vibrant colours, and the best damn skybox ever, which looks absolutely stunning in the morning and evening (in-game day/night cycle)

Audio: Excellent OST (free DLC) that takes me back to the game every time I listen to it. Peaceful ambience during gameplay which sadly isn't included in the OST. Sound effects work very well with the game's aesthetic.

Gameplay: Once the plot was established and I was comfortable with the controls (which did not take long at all), I felt totally immersed, all the way till the end.  Exploring feels great and I really felt like I earned the upgrades (which are super useful). You have the freedom to progress at your own pace and failure is not punished. Excellent map design with lots of nooks and crannies to explore. If the map was a procedurally generated planet I'd probably never stop playing it. Wonky and adorable physics. Camera works well but I wasn't totally happy with it. Controller recommended.

Performance: You could run it on integrated graphics with low FPS, but I wouldn't recommend it. GPU requirements aren't much. It would probably run better if it was written an updated version of Unity but it's fine. The game doesn't support it, but you can run it in borderless window mode with third party tools like Borderless Gaming. In-game options are adequate for a PC game.

Miscellaneous: M.O.M. from Grow Home and Toriel from Undertale are possibly the best game moms ever.

Conclusion: One of the few games that just made me feel good and provided an unforgettable experience in spite of its short gameplay.

I cannot wait to play this again in a year or 2 and be lost in its whimsy all over again.

reviewText:
BUY/SALE/PASS:  Buy

A darling little game from Ubisoft, you play as Bud as he works to grow a massive plant by riding growing vines to energy-laden stones in the sky.  The flat-shading and bright colors help make the game stand out graphically as the intrepid Bud just keeps climbing and climbing.  Jump, climb, float and fly, until finally you Grow Home.

Grow Home is a little Shadow of the Colossus, a little Tail of the Sun, and a whole lotta heart.  Bright colors and lovely vistas keep your rapt attention as you climb higher and higher, collecting gadgets to help you raise this little sapling into a plant that stretches out into the stratosphere.

While the game is relatively short (ironic given the insane heights you eventually climb to), this helps the game in the long run; rather than let the game run its course and go stale as it drags on and on, the game ends pretty swiftly.  It can be tough to buy into a game that generally lasts about three hours without collectables, but so long as you’re aware of what you pay for, I think it’s easy to find a lot of enjoyment in this fun adventure.

reviewText:
Grow Home is an open-world adventure game with alot of platforming in which you control BUD, a cute little red robot with limited abilities. He can climb, jump and move really clumsy... You start on an island and you have to gather crystals to gain your abilities back and you have to grow a plant to reach MOM's spaceship.

The game is very fun and the robot is hilarious with the way he moves, albeit being a bit frustating to control as a result of this. It's all for the best though, this game is great as is and I enjoyed it alot. The platforming is not too easy, you need to really learn how to control BUD and you need to be careful while climbing.

It should take you a good 5 to 7 hours to finish the game, which is quite resonable. I recommend you to try it out as I don't want to spoil anything about the game, even though there's not much story involved. If you like platforming and cute little robots though, this game is definitely for you!

reviewText:
I am giving this little gem a thumbs up.

I got the game from Ubi Humble Bundle and I must say that I would recommend this game to anyone who likes puzzels and exploration games.

You are a cute little robot called BUD and you're sent to this planet to grow your plant and explore and scan the wild life.

Most of the game time you will spend climbing with his sticky hands and falling from afar. Collect crystals and grow your plant to connect it to some yellow rocks that gives your plant more energy to grow. You climb up and up and up untill you probably reach the end.

The graphics are nice and cute, BUD is really clumsy but that don't interupt your game it's just fun to see him fall on his face from the surface ...

Overall this is a nice small game for exploration and solving puzzels also collecting crystals finding secret caves and scaning the wildlife of the planet.

reviewText: Through the combination of a simple, yet unique, objective and a charming art style Grow Home offers what I think is best described as a pleasant" game experience. Your goal is a direct one: grow a flower up into space by climbing on and guiding its various limbs to floating islands in the sky. And while it's not a dense
hoursPlayed: the journey you will embark on to accomplish your goal is anything but boring.\n\nThe climbing mechanic while a bit tedious at first
voteText: soon becomes second nature. And once other platforming mechanics are introduced
helpfulPercent: traversal becomes a breeze and at many points even enjoyable and satisfying. As you move higher the environments will begin to change in subtle but interesting ways
votesHelpful: thus affecting how you move and slightly altering the game's difficulty. At times the climbing can be tense
votesTotal: especially if you haven't activated a teleporter in some time as falling means you will need to start over from the last one. And because of this design choice
votesFunny: the spaces between teleporters actually resemble and function as interconnected levels. The entire journey is a bit slow going
commentsCount: but as I looked up into space and realized I was getting closer and closer to the ship
column16: I couldn't help but become excited and proud of how far I had come.\n\nIt is acutely innocent in its design and its tone is best described as a medium between cheerful and relaxing. The ambient sound design and minimalistic polygonal graphics are not only easy on the senses but also characterize the world as being clean and untouched. M.O.M.
column18: is charmingly written and is often humorous in her observations. Most times she resembles a caring mother who is proud of your accomplishments and at others
column19: a close friend who can't help but laugh when you hurt yourself.\n\nIn addition to the completing the main objective
column20: you also have the option of collecting power crystals and scanning the various plant and animal species found throughout the game. Both of these tasks can be a bit tricky and time consuming but provide useful upgrades or additional commentary. And by completing all three objectives you can be sure you'll have gotten your money's worth out of this incredibly charming game."

reviewText: Grow home is a game made by Ubisoft Reflections,which has made cool games like Driver San Fronsisco and the Just Dance games. This game didn't have much of a gigantic release, like the other games I mentioned, but it definitely desreves one. Grow home is a game you can complete in 3 or 4 hours at regular, and is about a robot named B.U.D trying to grow a plant large enough to get to the mothership he was sent out of. I reccomend using a controller for this game, due to the fact that the game is confusing to control with a keyboard and mouse. There is in-game skins you can give to B.U.D, allowing you to change his color/ style, yet I like the original skin the best because the alternate skins seem a little bit wierd, rushed, or bland. Besides its problems, which are mostly small features and difficult to reach places on the map, its a fun game with high replay value. My rating? 8.5/10,\nIf it had full ragdoll it would be 9.25/10

reviewText:
Grow Home is probably one of the best 3D collectathon platform games to come out in a long time, but it still has it's flaws.

PROS
-A Vertical open world landscape to explore
-Optional Side Missions
-3D Platform Game Goodness
-Low Price

CONS
-Awkard Controls
-Game is short
-No Compass or Map
-Too many branches can cause lag


STORY

The games story is a simple one.  You play as a robot named BUD & your goal is to collect a Star Seed.  The Catch?  You have to grow a ginormous plant first in order to get one.  Your guide throughout this adventure is MOM, an interactive AI of sorts that comments on what you're doing & gives you hints along the way.  That's really all their is to it.

GAMEPLAY

The gameplay is as basic as it gets.  You move, you jump, & you collect upgrade crystals to enhance your abilities.  You also can climb nearly any surface by using the L&R triggers to latch onto them.  It involves constantly swapping between the two triggers, which can get a bit monotonous at times.  The upgrade crystals are almost mandatory as well.  You need to gather at least some of them before you can even jump or zoom out the camera.  Eventually you get a jetpack & this helps the most throughout the entire game.  Getting at least 80 crystals to fully upgrade the jetpack is highly recommended.  There are 100 crystals in total & the last upgrade is given when you collect them all, the last being infinite jetpack which is more fun than it sounds. This seems a bit game breaking but you can't really get all 100 until you've been through about 95% of the game so it feels like an accomplishment once you nab it. It also serves as an easier way to finish anything you might've skipped or missed.  I'll admit, once I got all 100 gems I spent at least an hour just flying around goofing off & that alone was pretty fun.

The movement & jumping can be floaty at best & wonky at worst.  This game is physics based so there is a momentum system that can work with or against you & when it's against you oh man is it against you.  It doesn't happen often but when it does it feels like you're fighting the controls like you're on a mechanical bull ride & trying to steer it properly through a rapid river.  This is especially apparant when trying to grow out the stems in order to reach new floating islands.  When you grow a stem you can steer it in roughly the right direction but sometimes it will just flat out ignore you & go where ever it wants.  Thus, leading to you having to grow out another stem in the process.    As you grow out more stems & leach more green energy from the earth your main plant grows until when you finally reach the very top it sprouts & gives seeds.  You need at least one of these seeds to complete your main objective, afterwards the credits roll & you get a new objective to gather 8 more seeds which have been dispersed throughout the level.

The biggest issue I have with this game however isn't the awkward floaty controls, mind you that's still an annoying issue.  It's how easy it is to lose your sense of direction.  There is absolutely no compass or map system in the game so you can't tell which way is North, South, East or West.  This gets especially frustrating at high altitudes where there are little to no landmarks to make visual paths & you need to head in certain directions for certain objectives but have no clue where exactly that one floating island you need is located.  They really should have added a compass or map of some kind just so you know which direction you're facing.

GRAPHICS

The graphical presentation is very unique & stylized.  It's all very pleasing to the eye, imo.  The game is polygonal but not in such a way where it's distasteful.  It reminds me of early PSX games like Spyro or Crash Bandicoot.  Everything looks great overall.  Kudos to the designers on this one.

Performance Issues

After playing the game for some time I've noticed that after creating many more branches stemming from this large super tree, the game starts to lag considerably.  I've gone from a solid 40-60FPS to a grinding 20-30's on my current save file.  And with the controls being so awkward you need every little frame you can get, so if you're on a lower end PC like I am you might want to avoid this serious mistake I've made with growing too many branches.

OVERALL

Overall, the game is fun & has a bargain price.  I got around 8 or so hours out of it to complete the game 100% on my first play through, not counting achievements.  Control & technical  problems aside, it's a very fun game in a genre that is much overlooked in today's industry.  I hope to see more games like this in the future.

reviewText:
A simple, silly little game where you grow a plant to insane heights by burrowing its offshoots into energy rocks!
Along the way, collect crystals and floating utilities to allow for an easier time.
While B.U.D. can grab anything and climb like a ball of glue, like a ball of glue there is a limit how fast he can fall before his hands fail and he smashes! Oops!
Don't worry, the game gives 'ample' teleport oppertunities to make your exploring and collectable cleanup a breeze. Don't forget to experiment with the plants; some have strange effects!
All in all, a very fun game with stuff to experiment with. Some people might say 8 euros is a little much; I'm on the fence. It's a joy of a game, but I can see some might want to wait or a sale.
If you like adventuring and don't mind a little momemtum-heavy platforming, Grow Home can certainly get you your fix!

Good:
- Colourful
- Real sense of accomplishment
- Interesting climbing mechanics
- Good physics once you get used to them
- Good art style!
- Lots of interesting flaura and fauna
- Spooky caves! No actual ghosts, though.
- Unique objective and setting
- Jetpacks that, eventually, are good

Bad:
- The physics are... unique. Very heavy momentum there, BUD.
- Some collectibles are downright stupidly odd in their placement.
- It can take a while to climb places
- Sometimes, just sometimes, you can't really make it over that ledge and it hurts
- The camera-based aiming of the hands is annoying when moving across certain angles
- Glitches out on controls a lot
- Why is Jetpack/jump on the same button as zoom out on controllers?
- Shoots are hard to control properly. I guess they're supposed to be wild.
- Camera has issues

Final Verdict: A must have for someone looking for something new and fresh amongst those wacky boring sandboxes.
A solid 9/10 if it fixes the issues I mentioned, but currently a mighty 8/10! :D

reviewText:
One of the coolest, most creative, most original games I have played in a long long time. If you're sick of every game being just a derivative of some other game you've already played one hundred times before, then I recommend grabbing this one if you'd like a rare breath of fresh air.

Main objective is simple:
1) Climb the trunk to reach the buds and grow them into branches that reach out to the crystals in order to make the trunk grow taller.
2) Climb the now-taller trunk even higher and repeat step 1.
3) Grow the trunk all the way to outer space.

Side objectives:
1) Collect the crystals hidden all over the islands to power up some simple robot abilities.
2) Collect specimens and load them into the teleporter/analyzer for research.

That's really all there is to it. On paper it sounds like nothing, but the climbing mechanic is so unique and growing the stalks is so original that it's just plain enthralling somehow.

On my own scale below, I give this weird little game the full seven:

7) A classic, essential, and/or must-buy game that is worth full price.
6) A good game that is worth the full price.
5) A pretty good game worth checking out—especially if discounted.
4) A pretty good game, but I would recommend buying it discounted.
3) Worth checking out, but I would recommend buying it heavily discounted.
2) Only worth checking out if you are dangerously curious.
1) Avoid at all costs.

reviewText:
This game feels highly overrated. The gameplay doesn't feel good, which is a shame because you only have 4 controls; jumping, a flower parachute, left hand and right hand. The jumping feels super floaty and I always have to near instantly use my parachute to get going in the original direction I intended. Running around also feels awkward because of the odd way the character moves, I can only really describe it as feeling like walking in syrup.

You spend most of the game climbing, and I feel this is where the game shoots itself in the foot. Firstly, the climb is boring and repetitive as all you have to is alternate between two buttons while holding forward. I'm shocked to find myself preferring the climbing methods of games like Assassin's Creed, as while those games have very simplistic climbing controls, they don't force you to monotonously press the game two buttons over and over, metre over metre.
The biggest issue I have with the climbing is how moving the camera to look around and the frankly beautiful and very stylised scenery is difficult to do while moving. I wanted to break up the boring gameplay by being sucked into this wonderful world but upon turning the camera my character begins to fall. You are forced to stare at this little robot, who takes up far too much of the screen, as he climbs this solid green beanstalk and nothing else. Jump pads to help somewhat to alleviate this but that doesn't stop the controls and gameplay feeling so unpleasant.

I'm incredibly disappointed with this charming looking game. There's not much in here for gameplay nor story, and both failed to pull me in enough to want to ever revisit this. All it really did was make me want to play Shadow of the Collossus.

reviewText:
A diffferent adventure in a different world setback by awkward controls.

In Grow Home, you literally try to grow a plant to your freedom. The idea and the world is interesting, but sadly it doesn't provide enough content to make you see the end, mostly because of the awkward movements of the main character.

Obviously the movement is intended to be that way, but it also makes it VERY frustrating after you fall all the way down so many times because your character slides, moves and bounces around by itself.

I finished more than half of it and really don't recommend it. If you like to go back to a checkpoint because of a mistake you didn't make and try and try again, you'll probably like it. I just can't stand losing progress because I can't control the character properly.

reviewText:
Cute, enjoyable and made my trigger fingers hurt!

Many companies when they try and use the left and right triggers to represent climbing in a game fail. Just a fact.

Grow Home does not fail in this. And that's good, because 95% of the game will involve you climbing something.

This procedurally animated offering from Ubisoft leaves you wondering two things...

1) What exactly IS procedurally animated?
2) Why is jamming the business end of a plant in to floating rocks such an appealing way to waste a few hours?

The answer to the first question, if Grow Home is to be believed, is a robot that is entirely too awkward to have passed any level of design and specification checks during it's development.

The result, in game, is a robot that controls like a drunk toddler. This is not an impediment to be taken lightly since your overall goal will probably leave you running around on narrow platforms 2 kilometers above the surface!

The answer to the second question is... honestly... I have no idea.

Grow Home is bright, attractive, and beautifully executed. The restart points are just common enough that you don't get too frustrated by a long fall, but far enough apart that the 10 minute climb you just attempted and failed at the last second is certainly describable as some level of challenging.

The robot... B.U.D... you see, he's a plant-nurturing robot... get it? Nevermind... moving on, is dropped on a planet with very little power, the ability to acquire abilities in a number of ways and the instruction to make a star flower grow to 2,000 meters.

I suppose there is a reason for this - but BUD doesn't really care.

BUD can pick up power crystals - which turns out ot be a currency system to unlock new abilities!

He can also acquire some items to aid him in his quest. Or, mitigate the penalties of failing to control him during highwire movements high above the surface. Either way, useful thingies.

And then there is the climbing...

Lots and lots of climbing.

And Climbing...

M.U.M. will offer you plenty of encouragement, so that's an incentive for ya!

This $8 dollar game is well worth a look - especially if sticking to bricks and rotating a floating dodo is your thing.

reviewText:
If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText: In any platforming game the most important part of the game is the controls. And in this game they are horrible. You attempt to move up a slope and the robot starts sliding; you try to jump and go airborne and discover you can't jump off a certain slope. You attempt to use a leaf to glide back to where you were, and the leaf randomly twirls off and floats to the ground, leaving you to spend a minute at terminal velocity deciding if you'd rather shatter on the dirt, break up on the planet, or drown in the ocean.\n\nAgain, the main issue is that the controls are so bad they actively draw you out of the game as you struggle to make the robot do something as simple as move up a ten degree incline, and in a game where the objective is climb really high" this is a serious problem. It's like trying to play a 2D Mario game using the controls of QWOP
date: instead of simply moving left and right and jumping you're left flopping around until a goomba gets you. The experience playing this game is indeed quite similar; and even if you manage to get past the controls
recommended: you're left with a very shallow

reviewText: Grow Home does a good job of satisfying my itch for discovery in gaming. The game asks the player to find some way from point A to point B and lacks any sort of immersion-breaking barriers like invisible walls. The game has some ostensibly finicky mechanics that have a learning curve, but are very robust once you actually master them. Collecting everything in the game wasn't immensely rewarding or necessary to complete the game, but I don't think that really matters much, because I found the act and challenge of collecting them very intrinsically satisfying. My only real complaint is that I think, of the six hours I've spent playing at the time of this review, I spent probably half of the time searching for the last 1% completion I needed, which can get tedious if you're really obsessed with getting everything. I think it's worth stressing the importance of having your speakers turned up, in order to take advantage of the game's subtle audio clues. That said, I found the game very enjoyable for what it was, and well worth the $10.

reviewText:
Grow Home: Ubisoft's little indie-like darling; since it's finally hit the Humble Bundle, this little unknown game is going to get in the hands of many more people. Now then, the question: is Grow Home worth playing?

BUD, the adorable little robot, has one goal: to collect the seeds from a giant plant which will only bloom once it reaches space. To do so, he must nurture this incredible plant, guiding its growth and feeding it.

This game was Ubisoft's take on procedural animation - you, the player, control BUD's arms as he climbs, jumps, and stumbles his way up the giant plant. The plant itself grows in different directions based on how you control its nutrient-suckers, and you can create walkways and climbing walls for you to fall on or climb back up if you slip.

This little game oozes with charm. The world is minimalistic and colorful, the music is soothing, and BUD is adorable (if clumsy). Even if the game isn't a true sandbox, it's certainly a fun little playground to jump around in. While the controls are hard to get used to and can feel rather clunky at times even with a controller, the act of manually climbing a towering structure feels much more deliberate and compelling than just pushing the up button in an Assassin's Creed game.

If you got this game for free or as part of a bundle, I recommend taking a look - it's a more laid back and relaxing title that's only a few hours long, and it's one of Ubisoft's more imaginative titles. As for whether it's worth buying outright, that depends; I bought it for $5 on a sale myself and, even though I only played for a few hours, I still thought it was worth it.

reviewText:
Currently on sale for 1€ as part of the Humble Bundle, a great experience for the price [https://www.humblebundle.com/]

Grow Home is an exploration game in which your objective is to grow a giant plant by growing its vines into glowing islands. During the course of this you will explore the relatively small but detailed environment of floating isles, discovering new flora and fauna and finding out new snippets of information on everything by scanning things. You'll unlock new abilities through collecting energy crystals.

Things that make this game worth playing+ An excellent freeform grab system, allowing you to control both your arms separately. Carry things, climb a mountain or do skydiving while grappling with sheep.
+ Nice exploration. Great attention to detail and plenty of secrets.
+ Good freedom of movement using grab, jump platforms and a few special items through a beatiful environment.
+ Charming looks; not everyone enjoys it but personally I found the game gorgeous.

Things that aren't so great- It's short: In about 4 hours I'd managed to see most of what the game has to offer, save for finishing all the achievements.
- Hunting for the last few crystals is frustrating as the game doesn't give you hints about their location. Luckily searching for animals and plants is easier as tips are provided.


All in all it's a short but good game worth the asking price, especially since it is part of the 1€  Humble Bundle at the moment.

reviewText:
A very interesting experimental, physics-based platformer with novel traversal mechanics, Grow Home is unfortunately burdened by a number of flaws, ranging from poor level design (expect lots of tedious backtracking), anachronistic gameplay mechanics (expect lots of tedious hunting-for-hidden-collectables), and an overall lack of polish.

Many of the ideas in the game are good ones--ideas that the platforming genre rather needs, now more than ever--but the defining aspect of a platformer is not whether it has interesting or compelling ideas behind it, but whether or not the traversal mechanics are natural and enjoyable. And while Grow Home's traversal mechanics are interesting, and have a great deal of potential... they are insufficiently polished to be very enjoyable, and the tedious level design only exacerbates the problem. If I'm not having fun the first time I climb up a very tall vine to collect a glowing jewel, I'm not going to have much fun the 42nd time, either.

Grow Home also runs into the same problem every other physics-based platformer runs into: physics-based platforming simply isn't very enjoyable due to the lack of precision and control the player is able to exert over his or her avatar. If B.U.D.'s" movements were a bit more refined--if he could come to a stop more quickly and more precisely
date: if he could affect his descent with more accuracy
recommended: and project his leaps with more control... Grow Home would be a much better game.\n\nI'll keep a hopeful eye out for a sequel to Grow Home
hoursPlayed: or any other game that attempts to iterate on it--but by itself
voteText: this game is more a novelty than anything else: something to examine for a few minutes and marvel at

reviewText:

The feeling of height when climbing the world is the best i've ever experienced in any videogame, but there are also many, many flaws.

The 2 main flying mechanics have major issues: the parachute" stops momentum too fast and the gliding doesn't have a fast movement feeling.
The game is also way too easy
date: you have infinite tries to grow the tree and you will basically find no obstacles.\n\nThe physics can be enjoyable at times
recommended: but it's mostly really annoying when you can't place your hand where you want to during the climb. i get that the movement it's supposed to be "delayed" to increase the difficulty of the game but this is artificial difficulty

reviewText:
Quick, Clean, Fun!

Loved the concept of Grow Home; As well: The 'do no wrong' gameplay style where exploration, the visuals, and the quirky charm of this mini-world were the focal points of the title.

However, the price of the game, to me- is 'barely passable'. Unfortunately, it feels too short, and simplified to justify spending full price on. As well- there's no replay value whatsoever.

I would recommend this game to any fans of the platforming genre, who are looking for a casual 8 hour time sink.
However, for those who really want their money's worth: Wait until it goes on sale.

reviewText:
I never thought stumbling around like an overly excited drunk could be so fun or intuitive.

In this game, you essentially play as a cross between WALL-E and Jack Sparrow. Adventuring around (or rather up) the landscape. Collecting trinkets that you find (crystals), and questing to grow that little plant once found in a boot, to the height of a mountain.

BUD (the protagonist) moves hilariously, using physics rather than animations to move; meaning if you change your mind on the direction your going, he sways about like a drunk, clambering over to the direction you've decided. Despite this, the controls are very instinctive (at least on a gamepad). It's great fun, and rarely a nuisance. My few failures were entertaining, and easy to recover from with some quick thinking.

TL;DR: A unique experience. Great fun for any age or gaming skill level. Gamepad Recommended.

reviewText:
It's different and interesting, which is always nice to see, but is a bit disappointing.

The cutesy walking is a pain in the backside and, while the climbing controls are novel, I found them frustrating more often than not.  It can be satisfying to get going but usually it's just a case of point the direction you want to go then left, right, left, right on the triggers of the gamepad.  Whatever your climbing towards rarely seems to be worth the hassle.  I have to say that the gliding is great fun and cheered me up a bit when I got to do it!  I recently also just got one of the more handy add ons going so maybe it becomes a lot more fun the more you stick at it.

Don't get me wrong it's not a bad game.  I  just think it's not that good and doesn't quite work.

reviewText:
Has a nice look and feel to it.

I had some awesome moments in this game with exploring the islands and the first encounters with the interactive parts of the environment, very nice.

When you are used to fast responding controls from other games, it took me a little while to get used to these very clumsy-and-cant-stop-or turn-immediatly controls, which made me i slip off egdes numerous times.

The actual gameplay... There isnt much to it and I found that it quickly got very repetitive. I really love this concept of exploring unknown sorroundings and playing around with stuff in it, but dont have the climbing, collecting and bud growing part take up all the game. To me that was just repetitive filling, and i might have just jammed 1, 2 and 3 grinding mobs in WoW.

Give the robot an infinite jet pack, remove collectable crystals, improve controls, dont make me bud grow til' my butt falls off and sell it for 2$ - i would give it 10/10.

4/10

reviewText: While I really wanted to like this game, I found that after playing through and reflecting on Grow Home I did not really enjoy my time with it.  The biggest problem I had with the game was its physics engine.  As you can see by the picture of B.U.D., the game's protagonist, the character the player controls is very top-heavy.  This leads to a lot of situations in which Bud will land on a platform, be carried by his momentum, and end up running right off the platform you intended to be on.  While this makes sense scientifically, it can lead to a lot of frustrastion.  Another problem I have with the game's physics accuracy is the grip function.  While you are trying to climb up or over obstacles while holding on to something, the effects of gravity will often act on the held item, which will cause you to drop it.  This leads to even more frustrating moments when you have to try climbing over the same ledge multiple times or even having to restart your game when you drop your item hundreds of meters into the ocean.  Jumping itself can also cause annoyances because the plane that you think you are jumping on doesn't always match up with the plane the game thinks you are jumping on.  There were enough frustrating moments like these that make me not want to recommend this game to anyone.

reviewText:
Grow Home is a 3D platforming game which centers around being a small robot who slowly climbs up a vine, guiding its growth into crystals to allow it to grow yet higher, so he can get back to his space ship and go home. With extremely loose controls, a dodgy camera, tedious mechanics, and no depth, this is a game to avoid, feeling more like a school project than a finished game.

Story

There is very little story to the game; there are a few bits of flavor text here and there, and MOM – either an AI of some sort, or a fellow being who is elsewhere in the universe – occasionally gives you hints or makes “wry” (non-voice acted) remarks on your progress.

Gameplay

The game centers about climbing around the game world, slowly growing your vine upwards. To grow the vine, you must crawl up the vine to various red flowers, which you can then command to grow outwards. Each of these will sprout bouncy leaves, to help you ascend a bit faster, and additional red flowers, to allow you to grow additional vines. There are 100 small crystals hidden around the various floating islands in the game, and collecting those power up your robot’s jetpack; there are also large crystal islands, which you must direct the growth of the vines into in order to grow the main vine higher and burst through various barriers and reach the top of the map. There are also a number of things you can drag into your various telepods – locations you can teleport back to when you die – which unlock entries in a data bank.
That is literally 100% of the gameplay, and it is very dull. The controls for your robot are terrible, and carrying things around is extremely tedious, as you can easily drop them while doing other tasks. Climbing is an arduous process of alternating clicks of the shoulder buttons, and is made all the worse when the surface is uneven. Jumping and using your jetpack feels a little better, but is still very awkward, and it is easy to miss jumps and fall to your doom. A few pick-upable items – a flower which slows your descent, and a glide leaf which lets you glide around like on a hangglider – do little to spruce up the gameplay.
All in all, the game is a very tedious process of ascending the vine and growing it outwards, then upwards, then outwards again; less than half an hour into the game, you have seen everything it has to offer. If you don’t bother to collect the collectables, you could easily beat the entire game in an hour, and you’d still think it was too long. Collecting the collectables is tedious – most of environmental items you collect for the databank aren’t too bad, but a few have to be lugged large distances while suffering from the dodgy controls.
The small crystals, on the other hand, are extremely tedious to find; the only hint to their presence is an audio cue when the camera is close to them, which means that at the end of the game, if you’re missing any crystals, finding the rest of them is a matter of pure chance. Many are hidden in places which aren’t readily visible while gliding around, making this primarily a job for consulting a FAQ – if you were bothered to do it, which you really shouldn’t bother to do.

Graphics

The game has graphics which would have been an embarrassment in the Playstation 1 era; they’re ugly and unappealing, and the creatures in the game look terrible. The only thing which looks at all passable is the world from great elevation; it slowly becomes increasingly spherical around the horizon, and from a great distance, the vines and islands look somewhat visually appealing. Unfortunately, you will spend very little of the game admiring this, and most of the game looking at low-resolution textures and extremely blocky polygonal vines.
I will, however, give the game credit for one thing - it is one of the very few games which gave me an actual sense of vertigo while navigating the environment.

Final Summary

There is absolutely no reason whatsoever to spend your time, let alone your money, on this game. If it was a school project, I might be impressed, but as an actual commercial release, it is just not up to snuff. It is boring, tedious, repetitive, and yet manages to annoy you even though the entire game is likely to take no more than a few hours to complete.
Save your money and your time and do other things.

reviewText: As much I love Ubi's recent budget titles, Grow Home is the first one I'd say is a dud. It looks charming but its ultimately boring, mainly because the platforming is really janky. Climbing is slow as hell and that's mostly what you'll be doing. BUD also has actual inertia to his running so you'll be flailing around and potentially falling off the tree you're making. It's not at all interesting and there's much better platformers you can play instead.
voteText: 7 of 21 people (33%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Controls really blow it for Grow Home. I played with both keyboard/mouse and gamepad. I already know there is very little content and total gameplay, which I could live with if it weren't for trying to control a character that feels like it is in low-gravity and on ice. I'm also not the hugest fan of the climbing mechanic. I mean its ok, but not enough here to build a whole game on.

Is this what happens when AAA companies try to dabble in indie-level game production? I mean its not terrible, and the core idea is ok, but this is more of a proof-of-concept than  some brilliant sleeper hit.

Because the climbing mechanic is front-and-center, the rest of the platforming elements suffered from many gaps that were too big/awkward to jump, and many knee-high ledges that I had to fumble over to get onto.

I will also mention that despite what it looks like, it takes a decent machine to run on full graphics. I played on 'low' setting on my laptop, and on highest on my gaming rig.

Watch some gameplay first, and be aware that there isn't much here as far as replay value. This feels like the freebie of the month on some console indie subscription plan.

reviewText:
This game looks great, sounds great is supposed to be great. But the 44 minutes I played game, was one of the ragiest 44 minutes of my life, the only time i got ragier in a game was when i couldn't get a single ♥♥♥♥ing horse in red dead redemption, and that was years ago. Now I hardly ever rage at games, if I get stuck i look on the internet, but this I can't fix, and it is deliberate problem, in most people's eyes it isn't a problem but in my eyes it is.

The controls are waaaaaaaaaaaaaay to over the top, I know it's meant to be like that but it's a serious problem in a game which has you scramble around high up ledges and small spaces the entire game. A billion times I'm walking to get a crystal thing next to the edge of a floating island, and I stop telling the guy to move so I don't fall off and because he went on just that little bit further and I fell of and died in the ocean after a ten minute climb to said island. Another thing was that even though the grab distance was in range and it was a flat vertical face, when I switched to the other arm it doesn't bloody work so I fall and die. Another thing was that when I grab onto the sticky outy pant growy bits and make it start growing, even if I'm holding on I just get flung off and die for the 50th time.

The last problem I had with this game is what made me write this review and delete the game was when the game tabbed out because another window opened the game glitched out and crashed when I tried to reopen it because of resolution errors, when I reopened the game and clicked play, it put me right at the beginning because there was no autosave, when I found out that I had to restart the entire game, thats what made me say ♥♥♥♥ THIS" and write this review.

reviewText:
This game is beautiful, charming, and easy to pick up. The graphical style brings this world to life, and B.U.D. is a silly, lovable character.

This game encourages exploration and patience with it's mechanics. As soon as you leave the ground level, the game never lets you go.

The only CON I would place on this game is that it's too short. I beat it in one playthrough (2 hours) with 99 crystals. But that is not at all a set back. It is a game of the likes of FEZ and Journey.

If you enjoy platforming, exploring, and the wonder of nature, this game is for you.

reviewText:
Grow Home is an Indie, open world platformer where you play as B.U.D (Botanical, Utility, Droid) in your attempt to collect all them crystals, yip yip, and grow a gigantic beanstalk to the heavens! Oh and grab some seeds and bring it to Earth or whatever.

On a more serious note your goal in the game is to grow a Star Plant large enough so you can harvest it’s seeds to bring back to Earth. Which you can do by connecting a Star Shoot into floating islands called energy rocks surrounding the large plant.

As this game is a platformer your main activities will consist of figuring out how to get to point A to point B to achieve your objectives. Though that may prove difficult at first since B.U.D is a heavy character with a lot of momentum and you will find yourself fighting with the controls like in games such as QWOP or Surgeon Simulator. But once you learn how to properly manipulate B.U.D you will find an incredibly enjoyable time as you jump, bounce, and climb your way up that would make Jack proud.

Littered throughout the level are multiple crystals that I recommend finding as you unlock more abilities the more you find. They are in no way necessary needed to complete the game but let me just say one word: jetpack.

The game has a voxel like aesthetic that it uses to full effect and just radiates charm. And though I’m not normally a graphics minded person, the graphics is what peaked my interest of the game. Music wise the game didn’t have much to offer but what I heard was pleasing to hear. Difficulty wise the game isn’t too punishing as long as you activated various teleporters scattered throughout the game that act as your checkpoints if you die or can use if you need to travel back somewhere quickly.

Overall I would say this game was incredibly fun and a great game for all ages though it may be a bit short (unless you decide to do the bonus objective after you beat the game the first time) and even though Ubisoft hasn’t been very up to par lately, if you’re into a casual platformer that’s a lot of fun then this game is a must buy at $8.

Here's a link to my video review, it ended up far longer than I intended, I had a lot more fun than I anticipated: http://youtu.be/wXcWDS3ULFs

reviewText:
First off, the Steam version of Grow Home DOES NOT REQUIRE UPLAY.

Ubisoft is under a lot of criticism these days, that all their AAA-games are virtually the same[games.on.net], that they totally overhype their games like they did with WATCH_DOGS, there are all the controversies about Uplay and there was that bug disaster of AC:Unity. Some people say that Ubisoft is generally becoming the new EA.
But I'll say one thing for Ubisoft: Paradoxically, they make their own indie games like Child of Light, Valiant Hearts and arguably Rayman Origins/Legends. Grow Home is the latest indie game by Ubisoft.

Grow Home is an exploration game that manages to not be a walking simulator. You play as a robot who is send to a small island on a planet far far away. On that island is a flower which you have to make grow up into the sky like a giant beanstalk so that it blooms up which in turn allows you to collect its seeds.
To make the flower grow, you have to make one of its buds grow and navigate it into one of the countless floating islands. That's what makes the game so interesting: It is organic. It's like a 3D platformer where you make up the levels while you play.
The (floating) islands also make up exploration places: there are upgrade crystals to find, checkpoints to unlock and secrets to find.

I had a lot of fun with Grow Home. 8€ is an absolutely fair price for the game.

reviewText:
Played a few hours.  Found it to be a fun and different game, reminds me of old games but is nothing like them.  The climbing mechanic works just fine with a mouse using the left mouse for left hand and right mouse for (you guessed it) right hand.
There were a lot of mechanics in the game unexplained, mostly to do with the various plants (possibly animals too?) around.  Some bounded you a bit, others might eat you.  I have no clue what other ones were supposed to do.  One type can fling you places, i had a bug where I was flung off the map.  Even that was fun.
Pros:
-Interesting gameplay.  You can play very simply and put one hand in front of the other or perform acrobatic feats (mostly unintentionally).
-The physics of it felt consistent.
-Cool style.
Cons:
-ANNOYING constant noise making.  It seems the game fears any moment of silents and fills it with nonstop electronic noises.  I thought it was the music but turning the music down didn't seem to help.
-Is that it?  One level?  It took me maybe 2.5-3 hours to beat it just strolling along, I could see it being less than 2 hours of play for many.  I started a new game, it appears to be the exact same layout.  That will get old REAL fast meaning replay value is very low.

Overall a fun little game for an afternoon.

reviewText: Grow Home is an absolutely delightful little exploration game that offers much enjoyment to those looking for a relaxing experience with a dash of originality thrown in. You play a robot who is stranded on a beautiful planet, trying to grow a huge Star Plant to get back home. The speed of progress is up to the player - you can power play your way through the most obvious routes quickly, or take your time and attempt to find all the power crystals that are sometimes growing in places not so obvious. There are also many fun details and secrets to be found for intrepid explorers who choose the latter play style. I found Grow Home absolutely worth its price, highly recommended!

reviewText:
Amazing. This is exactly the kind of game the industry needs for a platformer revival. I hope it sells well. I didn't even know about this game until yesterday. Watched the trailer, and immediately bought it.

The graphical style is simple but beautiful. Everything is low-poly, and looks like concept art come to life. The colors are vibrant and create this happy, child-like mood.

The gameplay itself is addictive, but nothing too complicated. You start off climbing and looking for crystals. As you progress, you'll gain powers and use these little red sprout things to climb higher, eventually reaching floating islands and waterfalls that look straight out of a painting.

There really isn't any music, only ambient sounds. B.U.D. makes little bleeps and bloops, you'll hear the wind blowing through the air as you hanglide (or skydive if you fall), or the sounds of a floating waterfall. All beautiful, and make it worth it to play it with the sound instead of listening to music.

All in all the game is really amazing. I can tell it's going to be short.  I've only had it for 2 days, but feel like I'm reaching the end. However, I hope more that this is a stepping stone, so other developers see that 3D platformers are still a viable option.

Maybe in the coming years, Grow Home and more beautiful platformers like this one will take the place on Gamestop shelves, where all the bleak FPS games used to sit.

reviewText:
Thoroughly engrowsing. Everybody who says this game is extremely easy to get into is right.

But I have to complain about something, and so I'll get on my soapbox: you really do not need to have an overlay that appears before every game telling the player that the game is best played with a certain type of control scheme. First of all,  everyone knows you can play games with controllers. Steam bends over backwards to let you know that you can play games with controllers. Second, you're wrong if the player is bad with a certain control scheme. For example, I found this game much more enjoyable using my mouse, since I wasn't running around alternately looking at the sky and the ground. So don't waste my time!

But I like this game a lot. TL;DR I am an ornery old man and this game is cute as hell.

reviewText: I have definitely been taken aback by this beautiful game. This is my first ever review and I know this is a game truly worth writing about. reviewText:
In ten hours of gameplay, I've beaten this game 3 times. I've found everything, unlocked all the skins, completed all of the sidequests. And yet, I feel quite contented with my purchase!

Grow Home is a charming game in my opinion. The character is unusually clumbsy, silent, and mostly likable. Movement is an unexpected challenge because you're given the freedom to literally go anywhere you want - and yet getting BUD to move in the right direction at the right time can be stressful. He bumbles and fumbles and sometimes falls over completely. With a little practice, however, he is more than capable for the task ahead. In fact, I found a certain satisfaction in learning and discovering more advanced movement combinations and shortcuts - your mileage may vary.

The game is short, as stated before - and there's no getting away from that. In my first playthrough I completed everything in the game within 4 hours. Subsequent playthroughs have been accomplished within an hour if you skip the fluff". Even still
date: I find myself going back for more. The new skins that you unlock are useable on further playthroughs and make an appreciable difference in the way the game plays out while adding some visual variety. Moreover
recommended: the world is just an enjoyable place to explore.\n\nGraphically
hoursPlayed: there's little worry about performance and very few options to change. You're given the choice of VSync
voteText: Fullscreen
helpfulPercent: and "Quality". That's it. The game does not support AA in any form without adding a launch command to run the game in DirectX 11 (runs natively in 9). Also
votesHelpful: there's no AF because there are no textures... Let that sink in for a minute...\n\nThe long-short: if you want to support a creative team and you enjoy games where the objective and reward is in the exploration and journey
votesTotal: you'll likely really enjoy Grow Home. At $7.99
votesFunny: I think the price is reasonable for the hours of entertainment it has provided me. Hats off to Ubisoft for an enjoyable title without all of the issues some of their more recent releases have had."

reviewText:
Grow Home is an incredibly charming little game about platforming and exploration, but with a concretely defined goal.  You control what is, for all intents and purposes, a drunken robot with the ability to grip any surface.  Using this ability, you climb the stalk of a giant flower, helping it grow ever taller by directing sprouts into nearby floating islands.  Along the way you hunt for crystals which enhance your platforming abilities.

That's pretty much it, but exploring the environment is quite fun.  There's a variety of stylized flora and fauna that don't particularly contribute to the gameplay, but are entertaining to discover and observe.

The game can be finished in a few hours and while I feel its simple mechanics actually still had a bit more life left to exploit, Grow Home is more than worth picking up at its debut price.

reviewText:
As mentioned before there is no UPLAY. Excellent.

Grow Home one of the most relaxing games I've played in a long time. A combination of incredibly composed music;  striking yet simple visuals that don't give me too much to focus on at the same time, a simple mechanism to control BUD and the freedom to explore the world the way I want too.

This is the big winner for me, it's my game. It's a game that I play in the role of the central character and not the other way round (which most other games tend to be these days). I can go look anywhere I want, I can do the main quest of the game if I want or I can throw rocks off the sides of bigger rocks if I want.

That level of freedom, which is rare in modern games these days, is what's great about Grow Home. I look forward to playing further itirations of the game and to see where Reflections can take it next.

this is my first review because this game is amazing.

i would imagine if you did not have a fear of heights, this game could give you one, and if you already did, you might just have a heart attack.

something about the sense of scale in this game is mind blowing. i went to all the rocks and some were up to 3 vines growth away from the main vine.

some advice if you get tired of climbing: use the growth mechanic as a transport. the vines go really far, and there is almost always another flower not far from the end. also, the hang glider can help you get across or back to the main vine. the game doesnt have to be all climbing.

i have 85+ crystals collected and 3 of the secondary missions collectibles remaining.

absolutely wonderful, and if it was somehow longer/had more to it, it would be worth at least $15 maybe even $20.

reviewText:
Grow Home is an Indie, open world platformer where you play as B.U.D (Botanical, Utility, Droid) in your attempt to collect all them crystals, yip yip, and grow a gigantic beanstalk to the heavens! Oh and grab some seeds and bring it to Earth or whatever.

On a more serious note your goal in the game is to grow a Star Plant large enough so you can harvest it’s seeds to bring back to Earth. Which you can do by connecting a Star Shoot into floating islands called energy rocks surrounding the large plant.

As this game is a platformer your main activities will consist of figuring out how to get to point A to point B to achieve your objectives. Though that may prove difficult at first since B.U.D is a heavy character with a lot of momentum and you will find yourself fighting with the controls like in games such as QWOP or Surgeon Simulator. But once you learn how to properly manipulate B.U.D you will find an incredibly enjoyable time as you jump, bounce, and climb your way up that would make Jack proud.

Littered throughout the level are multiple crystals that I recommend finding as you unlock more abilities the more you find. They are in no way necessary needed to complete the game but let me just say one word: jetpack.

The game has a voxel like aesthetic that it uses to full effect and just radiates charm. And though I’m not normally a graphics minded person, the graphics is what peaked my interest of the game. Music wise the game didn’t have much to offer but what I heard was pleasing to hear. Difficulty wise the game isn’t too punishing as long as you activated various teleporters scattered throughout the game that act as your checkpoints if you die or can use if you need to travel back somewhere quickly.

Overall I would say this game was incredibly fun and a great game for all ages though it may be a bit short (unless you decide to do the bonus objective after you beat the game the first time) and even though Ubisoft hasn’t been very up to par lately, if you’re into a casual platformer that’s a lot of fun then this game is a must buy at $8.

Here's a link to my video review, it ended up far longer than I intended, I had a lot more fun than I anticipated: http://youtu.be/wXcWDS3ULFs

reviewText:
First off, the Steam version of Grow Home DOES NOT REQUIRE UPLAY.

Ubisoft is under a lot of criticism these days, that all their AAA-games are virtually the same[games.on.net], that they totally overhype their games like they did with WATCH_DOGS, there are all the controversies about Uplay and there was that bug disaster of AC:Unity. Some people say that Ubisoft is generally becoming the new EA.
But I'll say one thing for Ubisoft: Paradoxically, they make their own indie games like Child of Light, Valiant Hearts and arguably Rayman Origins/Legends. Grow Home is the latest indie game by Ubisoft.

Grow Home is an exploration game that manages to not be a walking simulator. You play as a robot who is send to a small island on a planet far far away. On that island is a flower which you have to make grow up into the sky like a giant beanstalk so that it blooms up which in turn allows you to collect its seeds.
To make the flower grow, you have to make one of its buds grow and navigate it into one of the countless floating islands. That's what makes the game so interesting: It is organic. It's like a 3D platformer where you make up the levels while you play.
The (floating) islands also make up exploration places: there are upgrade crystals to find, checkpoints to unlock and secrets to find.

I had a lot of fun with Grow Home. 8€ is an absolutely fair price for the game.
